contentrichtext.text: {{otheruses}} {{Taxobox | image = Vakorejsek ctyrprsty.jpg | name = Kowari<ref name = MSW3>{{MSW3 Groves|pages=24}}</ref> | status = VU | trend = down | status_system = iucn3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=iucn>{{IUCN2008|assessors=McKnight, M., Canty, P., Brandle, R., Robinson, T. & Watson, M.|year=2008|id=6265|title=Dasyuroides byrnei|downloaded=28 December 2008}} Database entry includes justification for why this species is listed as vulnerable </ref> | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[Mammal]]ia | infraclassis = [[Marsupialia]] | ordo = [[Dasyuromorphia]] | familia = [[Dasyuridae]] | subfamilia = [[Dasyurinae]] | tribus = [[Dasyurini]] | genus = '''''Dasyuroides''''' | genus_authority = [[Spencer (taxonomy)|Spencer]], 1896 | species = '''''D. byrnei''''' | binomial = ''Dasyuroides byrnei'' | binomial_authority = [[Spencer (taxonomy)|Spencer]], 1896 | subdivision_ranks = [[Subspecies]] | subdivision = * ''[[Dasyuroides byrnei byrnei|D. b. byrnei]]'' * ''[[Dasyuroides byrnei pallidior|D. b. pallidior]]'' | range_map = Kowari.png | range_map_caption = Distribution of the kowari }} The '''kowari''' (''Dasyuroides byrnei''), also known as the '''brush-tailed marsupial rat''', '''Kayer rat''', '''Byrne's crest-tailed marsupial rat''', '''bushy-tailed marsupial rat''' and '''kawiri''', is a small [[carnivorous]] [[marsupial]] native to the dry [[grassland]]s and [[desert]]s of central [[Australia]]. It is [[Monotypic_taxon|monotypical]] of its [[genus]]. ==Description== The kowari is 16.5-18 cm long, with a 13-14 cm tail. Its diet consists mainly of [[insect]]s and [[spider]]s, but probably also small [[lizard]]s, [[bird]]s or [[rodent]]s.<ref name = MSW3/> It is known as a voracious [[predator]]. It lives in underground [[burrow]]s, singly or in small groups. It emerges to hunt among [[Tussock_(grass)|grass tussocks]] for food. It breeds in winter, from May-October, and gives birth to litters of 5-6 young after a [[gestation]] of 32 days.<ref name=MSW3/> The kowari is coloured ashy-grey, and its distinguishing feature is the brush of black hairs on the end of its tail, which differs from that found in the [[mulgara]]s (''Dasycercus'') in that it completely encircles the end of the tail. They have a life span of 3-6 years.<ref name=Strahan>{{Cite book|last1=Aslin|last2=Lim|first1=H.J.|first2=L.|contribution=Kowari|title=The Mammals of Australia|year=1995|publisher=Reed Books|pages=59â€“61|editor-first=Ronald|editor-last=Strahan|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> ==Habitat== The kowari is found in stony desert areas of the [[Lake Eyre]] [[drainage basin]], in north-eastern [[South Australia]] and southwestern [[Queensland]]. West of Lake Eyre it is declining, and is now possibly [[extinct]] in this area.<ref name=Menkhorst>{{cite book|first=Peter|last=Menkhorst|year=2001|title=A Field Guide to the Mammals of Australia|publisher=Oxford University Press|pages=52}}</ref> ==Classification== The kowari is the only member of its genus. The genus name, ''Dasyuroides'', indicates that it resembles ''Dasyurus'', the [[quoll]]s. First described in 1896 by [[Sir Walter Baldwin Spencer]], it was for some time included in the genus ''[[Dasycercus]]''. The Kowari is a member of the family [[Dasyuridae]], and is most closely related to the [[mulgara]]. Two subspecies of the kowari are recognised:<ref name=Strahan/> *''D. b. byrnei'', found in the north-eastern part of the range *''D. b. pallidior'', found in the south-western part of the range ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.animalinfo.org/species/dasybyrn.htm Animal Info on the Kowari] {{Dasyuromorphia|D.D.}} [[Category:Dasyuromorphs]] [[Category:Mammals of South Australia]] [[Category:Mammals of the Northern Territory]] [[Category:Vulnerable fauna of Australia]] [[Category:Marsupials of Australia]] [[Category:Monotypic mammal genera]] [[Category:Animals described in 1896]]
